blogs.title: Meta debuts generative AI features for advertisers
blogs.author: Sarah Perez
blogs.content: Meta announced today it is rolling out its first generative AI features for advertisers, allowing them to use AI to create backgrounds, expand images, and generate multiple versions of ad text...
blogs.matter: The rise of generative AI is reshaping the digital advertising landscape by providing brands and marketers with new creative tools that go beyond traditional advertising methods. As Meta introduces its generative AI features for advertisers, it’s clear that we’re entering a new era where personalization, efficiency, and innovation will be the hallmarks of successful ad campaigns. Using AI to create dynamic backgrounds, adapt imagery to different formats, and tailor multiple variations of ad copy is empowering brands to engage consumers in fresh, relevant ways. This not only enhances the creativity behind each campaign but also ensures advertisers can quickly respond to changing trends and preferences. For businesses, this could mean reduced costs and time spent on designing ads, while consumers might experience more targeted, visually appealing advertisements that resonate on a personal level. As AI-generated ads gain popularity, brands can experiment more freely without the burden of extensive design processes. They can now focus on crafting strategic messages, relying on AI to handle the visual elements. Meta’s latest AI tools are just the beginning, signaling that in the near future, we might see AI fully integrated into every stage of ad creation—from concept development to real-time optimization. Marketers who embrace these changes will have a competitive edge in delivering compelling content across platforms. However, it also raises important questions about the ethical use of AI in advertising, including concerns about data privacy, transparency, and the role of human creativity. Nevertheless, the combination of AI and advertising is poised to drive significant transformations in the industry.

blogs.title: Making wearable medical devices more patient-friendly with Professor Esther Rodriguez-Villegas from Acurable
blogs.author: Darrell Etherington
blogs.content: Welcome back to Found, where we get the stories behind the startups. This week, our old friend Darrell Etherington joins Becca Szkutak to talk with Professor Esther Rodriguez-Villegas from Acurable...
blogs.matter:
In this episode of Found, we delve into the innovative world of wearable medical devices with Professor Esther Rodriguez-Villegas from Acurable. The discussion centers around the evolution of these devices, which are designed to monitor health metrics while ensuring comfort and usability for patients. Professor Rodriguez-Villegas highlights the challenges faced in making these technologies more patient-friendly, emphasizing the need for designs that cater to individual user experiences. Acurable has been at the forefront of this mission, developing solutions that not only gather essential health data but also encourage consistent use by patients.

The conversation explores various aspects of biotech and health innovation, including the integration of artificial intelligence to enhance data analysis and improve patient outcomes. Professor Rodriguez-Villegas shares insights into the collaboration between engineers and healthcare professionals, stressing the importance of interdisciplinary approaches in creating effective medical devices.

As the healthcare landscape continues to evolve, the role of patient-centered design becomes increasingly vital. The episode underscores how engaging with patients during the design process can lead to devices that are not only effective but also accessible and easy to use. Professor Rodriguez-Villegas encourages aspiring entrepreneurs and researchers in the health tech space to prioritize user feedback in their development cycles. This episode serves as a reminder of the ongoing efforts to bridge the gap between technology and patient care, fostering a future where medical devices seamlessly integrate into everyday life.

blogs.title: Rainforest raises $8.5M to help software companies embed financial services, payments
blogs.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
blogs.content: In November 2019, Andreessen Horowitz General Partner Angela Strange famously declared that, “Every company will be a fintech company.” Specifically, Strange projected that — in the not-too-d...
blogs.matter:
In a groundbreaking move for the fintech sector, Rainforest has successfully raised $8.5 million in funding to empower software companies to integrate financial services and payment solutions directly into their platforms. This initiative aligns with the vision articulated by Angela Strange, a General Partner at Andreessen Horowitz, who famously stated that 'every company will be a fintech company.' This statement reflects a significant shift in how businesses approach financial transactions and services.

The funding round, led by notable investors, aims to facilitate the seamless embedding of financial tools, allowing companies to offer payments, invoicing, and other financial functionalities without requiring users to leave their software environments. This integration is crucial for enhancing user experience and streamlining operations for businesses across various industries.

Rainforest's platform is designed to simplify the complexities associated with financial service integration. By providing developers with the necessary tools and resources, the company positions itself as a key player in the growing demand for fintech solutions. As the digital economy expands, the ability to offer comprehensive financial services becomes increasingly vita.

blogs.title: Pow.bio says biomanufacturing is broken and its continuous fermentation tech will fix it
blogs.author: Christine Hall
blogs.content: Pow.bio intends to bring down the costs associated with biomanufacturing by reimagining of fermentation facility operations.
blogs.matter:
Pow.bio is on a mission to revolutionize the biomanufacturing industry by addressing what it sees as fundamental flaws in current fermentation processes. The company aims to significantly reduce costs and improve efficiency by rethinking how fermentation facilities operate. Christine Hall explores the innovative approach Pow.bio is taking to continuous fermentation technology, which could transform the landscape of biomanufacturing.

Traditional fermentation methods often involve batch processing, which can lead to inefficiencies and higher operational costs. Pow.bio's continuous fermentation technology promises to streamline this process, allowing for a more consistent and scalable production of bioproducts. By maintaining a continuous flow of raw materials and products, the technology not only enhances productivity but also reduces waste, making it a more sustainable option for manufacturers.

As the demand for biomanufactured products grows—from pharmaceuticals to food and beyond—Pow.bio’s approach could set a new standard in the industry. The company's vision aligns with the broader trends toward sustainability and efficiency in manufacturing, making it an attractive option for businesses looking to innovate.

With its focus on reducing costs and enhancing production capabilities, Pow.bio is poised to become a key player in the startup ecosystem, attracting interest from investors and industry stakeholders alike. The potential impact of its continuous fermentation technology could reshape the future of biomanufacturing, paving the way for a more efficient and environmentally friendly industry.

blogs.title: Recapitalization, $60M Series D support growth of e-commerce financier Clearco
blogs.author: Christine Hall
blogs.content: Today is news marks a turnaround for a company that is had its share of ups and downs over the past year.
blogs.matter:
Clearco, an innovative e-commerce financing company, is making headlines with its recent $60 million Series D funding round, marking a significant turnaround after a challenging year. Christine Hall discusses how this recapitalization not only bolsters Clearco’s financial position but also sets the stage for future growth and expansion in the competitive fintech landscape.

Over the past year, Clearco has navigated various ups and downs, facing challenges that have tested its resilience and adaptability. The new funding is a testament to investor confidence in Clearco’s unique approach to financing e-commerce businesses, which provides capital based on revenue rather than traditional credit scores. This model allows online businesses to access the funds they need to grow without sacrificing equity or control.

With this infusion of capital, Clearco is poised to enhance its product offerings and reach a broader audience of e-commerce entrepreneurs seeking flexible financing solutions. The company plans to invest in technology improvements, streamline its operations, and expand its marketing efforts to better serve its clients.

As the e-commerce sector continues to flourish, Clearco’s innovative financing solutions could play a pivotal role in supporting the next generation of online businesses. This recent funding round not only marks a new chapter for Clearco but also highlights the growing trend of alternative financing options in the fintech industry, catering to the unique needs of modern entrepreneurs.

blogs.title: Rabbit is building an AI model that understands how software works
blogs.author: Kyle Wiggers
blogs.content: What if you could interact with any piece of software using natural language? Imagine typing in a prompt and having AI translate the instructions into machine-comprehendable commands, executing tas...
blogs.matter: Building an AI model that understands how software works is a multifaceted challenge that involves various layers of complexity. At its core, such a model aims to interpret, analyze, and even predict the behavior of software systems. This requires a deep integration of machine learning, natural language processing, and software engineering principles.To begin with, the AI model must be trained on a vast dataset comprising source code, documentation, and software design patterns. By leveraging techniques like supervised learning, the model can learn to recognize patterns and structures within code. For instance, it can identify common programming constructs, variable relationships, and control flow, which are crucial for understanding software functionality.In addition to code comprehension, the model should also incorporate knowledge of algorithms and data structures. Understanding how different algorithms operate and the complexity involved in their execution is essential for the AI to provide meaningful insights into performance optimization and potential bottlenecks.Natural language processing plays a significant role in this endeavor. The model should be capable of interpreting comments, documentation, and user requirements written in natural language. This enables it to bridge the gap between technical specifications and human-readable explanations, making it easier for developers to grasp software functionalities and intentions.Furthermore, incorporating techniques from formal methods can enhance the model’s ability to verify software correctness. By understanding specifications and reasoning about potential errors, the AI can assist in debugging and testing processes.As the AI model evolves, continuous learning from real-world software projects and user feedback will refine its capabilities. Ultimately, such a model can serve as a powerful tool for developers, enhancing their productivity and fostering a deeper understanding of software systems, thereby facilitating the development of more robust and efficient applications.

blogs.title: Resy and Eater co-founder raises $24M for Blackbird, a restaurant loyalty platform
blogs.author: Kyle Wiggers
blogs.content: Blackbird Labs, a hospitality tech company whose platform helps restaurants stay in touch with guests and incentivize them to dine out more frequently, today announced that it raised $24 million in...
blogs.matter: Ben Leventhal, co-founder of Resy and Eater, has raised $24 million for his new venture, Blackbird, a restaurant loyalty platform leveraging Web3 technology. Blackbird aims to help restaurants build better customer loyalty programs by using NFTs and blockchain technology, although Leventhal emphasizes that the platform's success doesn't rely on users understanding the technical side. Customers can join a restaurant's loyalty program simply by tapping their phones on an NFC reader, which issues an NFT acting as a digital identity. The system tracks customer preferences and dining history, providing restaurants with valuable data while simplifying the experience for users.Backed by investors like Andreessen Horowitz’s crypto team and American Express Ventures, Blackbird focuses on independent restaurants that need advanced tools to compete with major chains like Starbucks and Sweetgreen. Despite the use of Web3, the platform minimizes technical complexity for both restaurants and diners, offering a frictionless experience. Leventhal hopes that Blackbird will empower small operators to enhance guest relationships and foster stronger community connections through innovative campaigns, such as the Summer Sweet Pass, which offered curated dining experiences.This marks Leventhal's third major project in the restaurant industry after Eater and Resy, and he aims to create a future where independent restaurants can thrive by leveraging cutting-edge technology
